definition.value: The totality of all processes through which a given disease instance is realized.

editor note.value:
Why isn't 'disease course' a subclass of 'bodily process'?  There is currently no definition for 'bodily process', but perhaps it is intended to capture only those processes that occur in the body that are "normal" or "non-diseased".  If this is the intended distinction, it will undoubtedly be very difficult to construct an acceptable definition that will even hold up in most cases.

APC

name: disease course
body: The totality of all processes through which a given disease instance is realized.

definition.value: A disease course that realizes a neurological disease.

children.name: neurological disease course
children.body: A disease course that realizes a neurological disease.

definition.value: A disease course which realizes multiple sclerosis.

editor note.value: This may belong under OGMS 'progressive disease course'. It is unlcear at this time how to make sense of the distinctions between OGMS disease courses. All realizations of MS, even the replapsing variant, are considerd progressive at some level of granularity.

One way to solve the problem of defining MS variants is with process profiles.

As instance of a mutliple sclerosis disease course contains an instance of a process profile (relapsing remitting, secondary progressive or primary progressive) which characterizes the degree of neurological functioning of the organism that bears the disease.

A class has been created to represent temporal parts of disease courses. However, the solution is still under development.

children.name: multiple sclerosis disease course
children.body: A disease course which realizes multiple sclerosis.

definition.value: A disease course part that is characterized by a pattern of relapses in neurological functioning followed by periods of remission during which functioning does not decrease and is at a lower level of disability than that of the relapse.

editor note.value: characterizes the degree of deficit and overall worsening in neurological function (eg- muscle weakness or paralysis, optical disturbances, ambulation, etc.), inlcuding frequency of relapse and remisison, in a multiple sclerosis disease course measured according to a standardized scale such as the Kurtze Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS).

children.name: relapsing remitting disease course
children.body: A disease course part that is characterized by a pattern of relapses in neurological functioning followed by periods of remission during which functioning does not decrease and is at a lower level of disability than that of the relapse.

definition.value: A disease course part which is characterizerd by a steady decline in neurological functioning without relapse or remission.

editor note.value: Part of a solution when process profiles were considered. Most likely this class will be deleted.

children.name: primary progressive disease course
children.body: A disease course part which is characterizerd by a steady decline in neurological functioning without relapse or remission.

definition.value: A multiple sclerosis disease course that is a temporal part of a relapsing multiple sclerosis disease course and is charaterized by a pattern of impairment in neurological functioning followed by periods of remission during which functioning continues to decrease but is at a lower level of disabilty than that of the relapse.

children.name: secondary progressive disease course
children.body: A multiple sclerosis disease course that is a temporal part of a relapsing multiple sclerosis disease course and is charaterized by a pattern of impairment in neurological functioning followed by periods of remission during which functioning continues to decrease but is at a lower level of disabilty than that of the relapse.

children.body: A disease course which realizes relapsing multiple sclerosis.

definition.value: A disease course that (a) does not terminate in a return to normal homeostasis and (b) would, absent intervention, involve an increasing deviation from homeostasis.

children.label_undefined: acute disseminated encephalomyelitis transient disease course

definition.value: Acute encephalomyelitis is a transient dymelinating disease course in which the patient has a single brief but intense attack of inflammation in the brain, or spinal cord, or optic nerve that causes damage to the myelin.

definition.value: A disease course that is a proper temporal part of a disease course.

editor note.value:
In the case of MS, the pattern (or profile) of progression of neurological impairment is a defining clinical feature. However, it is not clear how to represent this. 

Development of this class is at an early stage and is not yet ready for implementation. The goal is to represent stages of a disease course, such as early, late, relapsing, remission, and so forth. An acute phase can be seen as a stage in a larger diseae course. The current OGMS representaition for disease courses, stages and parts, is not adequate. Or, at least, it is not adequately explained.

children.name: disease course part
children.body: A disease course that is a proper temporal part of a disease course.

definition.value: The portion of a disease course that occurs before symptoms (in the generic sense of the term) present.

children.name: presymptomatic disease course
children.body: The portion of a disease course that occurs before symptoms (in the generic sense of the term) present.

definition.value: The portion of a disease course that occurs after symptoms (in the generic sense of the term) present.

children.name: symptomatic disease course
children.body: The portion of a disease course that occurs after symptoms (in the generic sense of the term) present.
